Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is setting up a trading desk to make markets in digital currencies such as bitcoin, according to people with knowledge of the strategy. BE11:27am

Following the initial announcement on 7th December GVC have
formally agreed the terms of the deal in a 2.7 announcement. The headline terms are unchanged - Ladbrokes Coral Shareholders will be entitled to 32.7 pence in cash, 0.141 ordinary GVC Shares and a contingent entitlement of up to a further 42.8 pence in principal value of Loan Note plus an upward adjustment for the time value of money by way of a contingent value right (CVR). Most importantly the synergy number has been confirmed at £100m (c€113m), slightly ahead of our assumed €100m.

HumbleEpictetus hello all!
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Synergy timing limited by PTEC deal — The timing for the full capture of these synergies may disappoint as the full benefits are not expected until 2021. £7m is expected in the first calendar year, £33m by yr 2, £56m by yr 3 and £100m by 2021. We think this timing relates to the end date for Ladbrokes Coral’s deal with Playtech. Moving Ladbrokes Coral’s operations away from the Playtech platform onto GVC’s proprietary platform will likely be a key part of the cost saving opportunity, although we expect the combined group will continue to use Playtech content. We expect Playtech to mitigate lost revenues to some extent with a content deal with the broader group.

Soundbuy Vectura - VEC average daily vol done already....
Superfluous now they're big enough to go for Ladbrokes they can shed the illegal stuff and go clean. Gotta hand it to Kenny, he pulled a masterstroke.
BE11:28am

 Strong management line up — Kenny Alexander (CEO of GVC) is to remain as CEO and Paul Bowtell (CFO of LCL) will become CFO of the combined group. We regard this as a very strong line up. Lee Feldman of GVC will remain as Chairman.  CVR details — There are more details on the CVR mechanism. In particular the
disclosure points to the formula for valuing the resultant loan notes which effectively limits the downside to EBITDA at £140m under a £2 triennial scenario (0p CVR value) and values the incremental EBITDA stream at 6x.
 Turkey goes — As part of the deal, GVC will be forgoing all deferred consideration for the disposal of its Turkish operations. GVC was meant to receive a performance related earn-out payable monthly up to a maximum of €150 million. We previously estimated the present value of the income stream to be worth €107 million.
 Retain Buys on GVC and LCL — We upgraded GVC to Buy (Target 1,090p) on the back of the deal given the opportunity for the combination to unlock substantial synergies and in the process create value for both sets of shareholders. Our LCL target is 200p. Assuming the bid succeeds, and based on the new Citi target price for GVC of £10.90, the implied longer-term Ladbrokes Coral valuation could be closer to 220p, subject to the same variation on the Triennial Review outcome.

BE11:28am

BornCynic Learned a useless fact from a Scottish person the other day (not you BE):Christmas Day only became a public holiday in 1958, and Boxing Day in 1974. The New Year's Eve festivity, Hogmanay, was by far the largest celebration in Scotland.
BE11:32am

1) Cost synergies phasing a little longer than expected but combined with procurement and revenue synergies, the total number is likely to be well in excess of £100m –

BE11:33am

Skipping synergies because it's dull.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

2) Turkish disposal news is a dis-synergy but is far outweighed by value of LCL deal – As part of the deal, GVC is waiving all rights to receive an earn-out from the sale of its Turkish business. This is a dis-synergy from the deal: GVC was expected to receive a maximum of €150m from the sale of its Turkish business over a 5 year period with company consensus expecting a cash inflow from payments in 2018 (albeit likely to be only c. 10-15% of €150m). We believe this indicates that the view here is clearly that the value creation from the deal with LCL far outweighs the value that will be lost from not receiving proceeds from the Turkish deal.

BE11:33am

4) Financing details – The CVR is covered by a loan note which is converted once the outcome of the Triennial review is confirmed (expected Q2/Q3 2018). The Loan Note Principal Value will bear interest at a rate of 7 per cent per annum from the date of issue of the Loan Notes for a period of six months and one day and at a rate of 9 per cent thereafter until redeemed by GVC. On redemption, the Loan Note Principal Value plus accrued interest will be repaid to the holders of the Loan Notes and the Loan Notes will be automatically cancelled. The cost of debt for the rest of deal has not been announced. In our illustrative merger model, we assumed a coupon of 3% but see small upside risk to that number given the combined leverage of the group. Finally we note that Ladbrokes Coral Shareholders will be able to elect to vary the proportion of cash and New GVC Shares they receive, subject to offsetting elections being made by other Ladbrokes Coral Shareholders.

Superfluous Big logistical challenge realising those synergies - I've heard the Bwin IT system which GVC inherited is a dud. Huge technical debt, can't even support standard UK offerings like each way in racing.

So, here comes Bernstein to say .... "nah, don't get excited."

BE11:41am

That this transaction is a prerequisite or a catalyst for the still elusive mother (or father) of all cable/mobile deals is thoroughly premature in our view. What it does signal though is that (i) LBTY is an astute trader of assets in its portfolio with a bias to sell its portfolio businesses at appropriate valuations, (ii) a 'TopCo' deal with Vodafone even ex-Austria is a zero-probability event, unless and until the 'TopCo' overlaps well with the Vodafone footprint and (iii) the LBTY assets with low-single digit growth prospects will still extract an attractive premium in line with a share of synergies of 40-60%. And despite this being a single-market transaction, it will likely further substantiate the lead role of the EU Commission in both the adjudication of such cable/mobile deals and its views on the need for remedies.

Otter Hello Christmas friends
Boncoeur cheers daz
BE11:42am

What, then, might the nature of a Liberty Global/Vodafone deal be? The jury is still out on whether LBTY can put VirginMedia back on a path to sustainable growth. And with Brexit a mere 15 months away, EU institutions are likely to bat back any request for merger control to the UK Competition & Markets Authority. This, in our calculus, implies that Vodafone and Liberty Global will likely pursue two separate transactions: one with Germany at its core but also encompassing the Dutch JV and Eastern European markets (Hungary, Czech Republic and potentially Romania); and the second involving the UK and Ireland. Today's announcement suggests that 2018 could potentially see the first of these two transactions materialize.

Today's deal just might be the start of an unravelling of the Liberty Global cable empire in Europe.

11:42 am

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Read-acrosses: LBTYA/VOD, Swiss market. The deal is modest for LBTYA, but, in our view, has significant read acrosses. First, the deal raises the question of an asset clean-up ahead of a possible VOD/LBTY deal. Unconfirmed news reports (The Telegraph, Nov 28) previously pointed to LBTYA’s potential interest in divesting its Austrian/Swiss operations for a better fit with Vodafone. The second read-across is to the Swiss market. UPC Switzerland has been underperforming, and while convergence is gaining traction, we think its convergence strategy is weak (UPC reacts, higher pressure for Swisscom). Swisscom is the only operator with fixed-mobile assets in the Swiss markets. However, mobile-only Salt plans to enter broadband. Additionally, data consumption is growing, which poses a risk to UPC's MVNO mobile model, and Sunrise is gaining share in fixed through wholesale access . In our view, UPC exiting the market would not offer a clear path to market repair. We would expect Salt to continue with its aggressive discounting policy - not good news for Swisscom, which holds more than 55% market share(UP, PT CHF356).

BE11:54am

Dividend and M&A are the key debates... GSK has underperformed by 13% since 3Q17 results, as debate around dividend sustainability has intensified. The 1.25x-1.5x dividend cover target is out of reach before 2021 in our base case and 2018 leverage of 1.6x (2.4x including the put option on Novartis' consumer stake) illustrates the constrained capital allocation at a time when the pharma pipeline is in need of rejuvenation. A potential decision to lower the dividend could hurt income chasers, however would have a positive impact on mid-term financial flexibility: we calculate that cutting the dividend by 50% would lower 2022 Net Debt/EBITDA from 1.3x to 0.6x, or that Glaxo would be cash positive in 2022 if the dividend were axed completely.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

... in the context of interest in Pfizer's consumer business. Management said on the 3Q17 call it would look into Pfizer's CHC business (covered by David Risinger). We think an acquisition on this scale would find strategic rationale, but put additional financial constraints on GSK and further limit flexibility to invest in the rest of the business. We flex our M&A model for different scenarios and, as previously noted, we see value creation as challenging in the CHC space given valuation reflected in recent transaction multiples.

GSK's valuation has significantly improved over the past few weeks and our revised price target is close to the current market price. Upside for our EU large pharma coverage ranges from +3% (AZN) to +45% (Shire) and our weighted-average upside for the sector is +8%.

11:55 am

GSK and Sanofi are therefore exceptions, with limited room for upside and complicated short/mid term outlooks, making them relative Underweights in this space. Today's small change to our target reflects lower comp valuations and reduced Advair sales and margins in 2018+.
